docs.lead_paragraph: A substance used to thicken shampoo and lipstick is now making its way into medicine, potentially improving the effectiveness of drugs to battle diseases like hepatitis C, diabetes and cancer. By itself, the substance, known as polyethylene glycol, or PEG, does not heal, battle germs or kill cancer, although it is prescribed as a laxative before bowel surgery.

headline.main: Cloaked in Stealth Molecules, Drugs Sneak Past the Body's Defenses

docs.abstract: Substance known as polyethylene glycol, or PEG, used to thicken shampoo and lipstick, is now making its way into medicine, potentially improving effectiveness of drugs to battle diseases like hepatitis C, diabetes and cancer; body almost entirely ignores PEG's, which makes them useful for medicines; when PEG's are attached to other molecules in process known as pegylation, body also ignores attached molecules, thus providing an invisibility cloak to drugs that otherwise would be dismantled by body's immune defenses or flushed out by kidneys (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The New Jersey Division of Consumer Affairs has proposed allowing doctors to write and transmit prescriptions directly to pharmacists by E-mail, Mark Herr, division director, said last week. Nationally, 7,000 people die each year and $95 billion in additional medical care results from errors in prescriptions, much of it caused by illegible handwriting by doctors, Mr. Herr said. The change in regulations is expected to be adopted by the appropriate boards within the next few weeks and go into effect by summer. Karen DeMasters
